text:
Animal crossing wild world is fantastic. If you like wild world may I advise you to get the gamecube version as well someday. Both games are absolutely charming and incredible. 

It's so sad what happened to the franchise. They seem to almost be purposelessly be removing charm from the game. They removed resetti from newer games for apparently making kids cry, they changed the artstyle from this lovely slightly muted but aesthetically pleasing one to a bright pastel cancer with horrible tacked on lighting effects and filters, the character models have become realistic for some reason and stick out like sore thumbs, and worst of all the older games have more features than new horizons, and people are fine with this because of updates after launch. Another awful thing is the writing, the villagers feel so soulless and empty in the newer games, the writing quality tanked. 

Utterly ridiculous, be sure to buy the gamecube version while you can. I feel the older games will be looked back on way better than new horizons which will age like milk and the gamecube and ds version will always be valuable. 

Have fun playing Jet.

text:
Imagine a prequel Animal Crossing game with a more structured narrative. â€˜Animal Crossing Originsâ€™ or something. I know that seems to immediately go against ACâ€™s design as an open-ended life-sim. But this could be sort of like a spin off! Youâ€™re still the resident human whoâ€™s new in town. Villagers still move in and out and get you to run around doing favours. The core game play is still pretty similar. 

The difference is that this is also an origin story for characters like Tom Nook and Redd. They live in your town like normal villagers and ask for favours and whatnot. But they have an involved story which unfolds at the playerâ€™s pace. You learn about their job aspirations and you see their conflicts play out in some depth. 
You (can choose to) help Tom set up a tiny little shop selling nicknacks. Maybe Redd is close to Tom, so starts helping him out. 
But Red has some questionable methods which rob Ton the wrong way. He often sells fake goods, or sells things at exorbitant prices. This angers Tom, and the two drift apart over time.
Thatâ€™s when the two place you in the middle. In a heated argument, they ask you whose side youâ€™re on. Your answer will make one of them move out of town. Maybe they leave permanent, but if you write to them enough, theyâ€™ll move back, and you can help patch things up with the animal who remained.

Another plot could feature Joan. She lives much further out from the others, in a dusty hovel near the cliffs. For the first few weeks, it doesnâ€™t seem like anyoneâ€™s home when you knock. But occasionally, when youâ€™re out wondering the forest, you see Joan planting and plucking turnips. She acts pretty distant and aloof, but might sell you some Turnips. The more you do this, the more she talks to the player. She eventually starts having more involved conversations, eg sheâ€™ll ask what the other villagers are like.
It starts to become pretty obvious that sheâ€™s lonely and doesnâ€™t speak to the other villagers, mostly just staying inside her far off house. Once she gets to know you, she starts inviting you over to her house. 
The closer she gets to you, the more confident and sociable she becomes. She will eventually start getting more involved with the community - maybe sheâ€™ll finally move out of her old house and into the central forest where the others live. Depending on how friendly you were to Joan, sheâ€™ll either: leave you her house for free; sell you her house at a modest price; sell her house to Tom Nook (which the player can then purchase at full price). 
Your closeness to Joan (and subsequently what she does with her house) could depend on several factors, like how much you spoke with her, your dialogue options, how many Turnips you bought, etc. One key way of increasing your friendliness to her would be delivering her mail to her. Maybe since her house isnâ€™t registered, her mail gets left at the post office. The player can choose to deliver it to Joan themselves. 

I think this approach could be really neat. Iâ€™d want the general vibe to be more like the Game Cube title. So, more slow, melancholic and acoustic music. The setting is a huge, sloped forest, with a river leading down to the beach. Thereâ€™s a big emphasis on nature. So buildings are mostly wooden and shack-like. Thereâ€™re lots of dusty trails and overgrown patches. The whole place is sort of like a big, nostalgic meadow. This is in contrast to New Lead and NH, which tend to be a lot more energetic and modern (still love them of course).

Tldr An Animal Crossing Prequel game featuring character backstories. :)

text: It wouldâ€™ve been October of 2008 perhaps (or shortly after), when I first played Wild World. Iâ€™d recently gotten a DS Lite for my 10th birthday and a few games, but a family friend of ours was really into â€œhackingâ€ etc, and gave me an R4 card for free with about 40 pre-installed games on it. Wild World was one of those, and I can literally pinpoint the memory of loading it up for the first time. It was a school night, I was up late in bed trying as many different games as I could on this R4 and obviously came across Animal Crossing. I was immediately entranced by the music, characters, everything. Iâ€™d never played an Animal Crossing game before then and ended up having literally a sleepless night ðŸ˜‚ if I remember correctly, I faked being sick the following day and just continued playing. Shortly afterwards I bought an actual Wild World cartridge out of respect for the game. Already owning a Wii, you can imagine how ecstatic I was when finding out Letâ€™s Go to the City existed. Definitely a massive part of my childhood, Iâ€™ve played every game since, but this one will always technically be the first for me.

text:
Your riding in a cab, riding to your new home, Karimu Village, located near a beach.
The rain would Sooth you as the car rocked slowly and gently, the driver would ask your name, you would reply with your name.
The driver would reveal his name, "Me names kappa, so why exactly are ye movin' to this ol' town, it's in the middle o' nowhere.."
you would respond with why, and the driver would nod his head, and turn on the radio.
the rain would slowly hault, revealing a beautiful town, it appeared populated, and there was nothing but sunshine and the clashing of waves faintly heard.
The trees would shimmer sunlight on you, filling you with nothing but happiness.

text: Wild world was my first, I remember all the fun times, I remember a lot, it was my favourite game on DS, I would play it all the time. text:
There's something so eerie about how quickly I'm launched back into my middle school/early high school days by this intro theme. The first few seconds I didn't recognize, but when 00:35 kicked in, I was immediately engulfed in a warm, nostalgic hug. I spent hundreds of hours with this game, easily, doing everything possible in it. So many late nights, up with my red OG Nintendo DS, listening to the game through a pair of Nintendo-branded over the ear headphones. Or at sleepovers with my friends, running through each others' towns, playing hide and seek or fishing or giving each other tours of our houses. I remember we were racing to see who could get their houses fully upgraded first... I ended up winning that race, as well as receiving the highest grade from the Happy Home Club.

I'm 26 now and that all seems like a lifetime ago. I'll cherish those memories forever, though.

text: I see lots of comments on how people have played this game with their cousins, family, friends and it's amazing to have such a brilliant childhood like that! Me and my sister used to play this game quite a lot with each other and sometimes, if my cousin was over and had her DS, she'd play with us. But for some reason she kinda stopped playing it with us, so it was just me and my sister playing it. We played with each other for a while (like I had said) then we kinda stopped recently, whenever I bring it up she tells me no, and she doesn't give me a reason for it. She's 11 and I'm 14, so she should still be able to play with me and I love the game. I know everyone's gonna be like, "oh but she's just growing up! That'll happen. Maybe she's just not interested in it anymore." But she loved that game, she strived to get a perfect town. She always asks me to play games with her, so she still wants to play games with me. Basically, I have no one to play with and I see all these stories how when someone was 14 they'd  play all day long or something like that. I just miss having someone to play with. Bye now

text:
I remember when I looked for people who had an Action Replay so they could give me millions of bells.
But even though I had millions of bells and lots of playtime... There was one problem. My hands.
Each and everytime my DS fell down while playing Animal Crossing, my data would be lost instantly. I had to redo all the crap over and over again each and everytime that piece of crap fell down. 
I had to keep asking my friends if I could go to their down and re-do my old hairstyle, give me a few bells for compensation, drop the DS again, and do it all over again.

Even though it was annoying, I found it enjoyable to do everything over and over again. Discovering old and pretending it was new... Trying to beat records... and the most important of all? Friendship.


Those are things the newest AC games won't do ever again. It just doesn't feel the same anymore.

someone had to teach us, i guess

text:
a Bear spot on, people just like to criticize the latest entry in nearly any series because they're biased towards older titles they spent years playing. It happens all the time no matter what the series is or how good the new game actually is, it even happens with Breath of the Wild. Watch how when a new AC game on Switch comes out and everyone will be complaining saying New Leaf was much better. Nostalgia sure is a strong thing. New Leaf is still a great game that's fun to play.

While being better than WW is debatable New Leaf is still leagues ahead of City Folk.
author: Seki

text:
I loved the little things you could discover in Wild World such as finding the Wisp or throwing axes into the fountain in City Folk. The short side story involving the Able sisters and Label was charming and brought something to the game in City Folk. A lot of things in New Leaf feel somewhat artificial, shop owners don't have as much personality. In City Folk, Redd was a sketchy dealer who remained somewhat mysterious when you could talk to him, but not enter his shop. Now he's just a guy who sells paintings. Kicks doesn't really have any personality traits. Before was just a guy who you can sit down, relax, and let him shine your shoes in the middle of a bustling plaza, which isn't much, but is still something.  KK Slider performs in a modern club, which doesn't give the homely atmosphere that was present in City Folk when he was played in the warmly lit Roost.

I'm referring to City Folk a lot because I played that game a bunch and remember the most from it. But from what I've seen, the gamecube version seems to be very charming as well, with other random events that can occur in your town.
author: Leaf

text:
You can blame City Folk for sucking all the soul out of villager dialogue and interactions while kicking off the modern AC mindset of "Everything needs to be cute and sterilized!"

I appreciate New Leaf for all its improvements, but Animal Crossing needs to go back to the atmosphere that Population Growing and Wild World had.
author: GuyWithThePie

text: I feel the same way, but I also think nostalgia is tricking us a bit here, New Leaf is honestly a more interesting game with more possibilities (though I do agree the dialogues are not as well done) and I think some of that "atmosphere" we're feeling is just the nostalgia. I always feel a very special way about stuff from my past, especially my childhood, and this is one of those things.
author: abendrot

text: Considering I only got into this franchise back in 2012, I don't think that's the case. I've played every game and it's clear to me that the atmosphere from Population Growing and Wild World is nowhere to be found in modern AC, it just isn't there.
author: GuyWithThePie

text:
Besides what's already been said about character dialogue, I think a lot of it has to do with the visuals and music.

Despite being N64 and DS games, the first two AC games still have the best lighting engines of them all. Everything just has so much more depth than CF/NL/PC's flat, near-cel shading. (Although NL's lighting is significantly better than the CF and PC's) The first game's top-down view also makes the world feel a lot more immersive than the rolling log introduced in WW.

As for the music? Well, the odd, experimental soundtrack of the first game has still yet to be topped, and I honestly doubt it ever will be. That being said, Wild World still has the best main theme (After all, why are we even on this video?) that truly captures the feeling of the AC franchise as a whole. It's no wonder every other AC-related track in Smash is an arrangement of it, while NL's lame theme isn't even part of a medley or anything.
author: GuyWithThePie

text:
Oh yeah, and last but most certainly not least is the game's overall premise. Something so simple that people often forget has been completely lost.

The main inspiration behind the first Animal Crossing was the feeling of moving out and living on your own, and the struggles that accompany such. This is also, at least in my interpretation, the reason why your character is the only human being in a town full of animals. You are an outcast, a completely new face trying to adapt in an already closely-knit community. And what's more, you're on your own. Your friends and family are far, far away.

New Leaf and all the spin-offs following it completely throw this out the window in favor of making the player this important, powerful figure from the get-go. From the moment you step off that train, everyone in town worships you as if you were the second coming of Jesus. It just feels... wrong. I really hope that AC Switch goes back to making the player just some ordinary kid, but I fear that won't be the case. The nu-fans that started with New Leaf, Pocket Camp, etc. are already too used to the idea of the player being the one in charge to accept such a thing.
author: GuyWithThePie

text: @GuyWithThePie New Leaf was my first AC game and it had that atmosphere for me, because I was a kid, and everything feels much more magical when you're a kid, so I didn't notice the npcs being repetitive, to me they were actual people living their life and if they said the same thing again I'd just talk to another one and go back the next day to talk to them again and I felt like that was normal. And then going online and meeting actual new people was also an amazing experience as a kid, somehow making friends in a virtual realm was something I didn't think possible back then, so yeah, I really think all AC games are good and they just feel different according to how much we grew up, I'm fairly certain the switch one will be awesome but that I wont be able to appreciate it as much as new leaf, just because I grew up and that now this won't feel as authentic. I'm super happy for you tho that you were able to experience wild world in all it's glory :)

text:
God how serious my friends and I played it back then. We'd meet up just to play that game, we converted our main rooms in our houses to "shops" for when the other visits, we took our villagers so serious.
I remember how I felt when I payed off my loan, how I felt when a villager celebrated my birthday with me, how I felt when I caught my first fish, heck even how I felt when I bought my first item and displayed it all proud in my house: I felt happy, a feeling full of such satisfaction and proudness I wish to experience some time again.

For those fellow Animal Crossing: Wild World players out there: Others might never understand but we do. Animal Crossing didn't only change lives, Animal Crossing was our childhoods. And it always will be.

text: I remember in high school, we had a free day in class and I asked my teacher if I could play on my DS for a bit. She said it was alright as long as I had the volume down. I forgot that my volume was up when I turned it on and this song played right when she was behind me. She stopped in her tracks and asked "Is that a game? That music is gorgeous!" When I said yes and showed it to her, she was ecstatic, saying that she didn't think games would have such pretty music. The next day, I brought in a CD of different game music (namely AC and Zelda) to play while we worked. She asked if she could keep the CD because she enjoyed it so much. Every year now, ever since that day in 2005, I have sent her a compilation disk of Game music she would enjoy.

author: quinlan723

text:
Ahhhhh... I remember when I firstÂ got this game. Me and my sister LOVED the first game and City Folk (I remember when she got them both). We would play them for hours on end, and even tried to get myÂ mom to play the first when we were little... ah memories...Â So I really wanted my own since she owned both. SoÂ around ChristmasÂ that year, I remembered that an old friend of mine's sister had an Animal Crossing game for the DS... called Animal Crossing: Wild World. I then asked my Aunt for it, and on Christmas Eve, got it. I remember playing it all night, and all morning. Soon enough though, I got new games, and forgot allÂ about Wild World, playing occasionally on holidays... I have started playing it again though, and hope to play it along with New Leaf. Sadly, my sister never got back into Animal Crossing, or video games period... so now I kind ofÂ just play them by myself, except with my (female) cousins every once and a while, probably because I am the only boy on that side, an on my other side I have a guy cousin, but he's "too old" to play video games, much less then even with me, his younger cousin to bond... And most kids would probably laugh at the fact that I only play Nintendo, since they play first person shooters... I wish I could re-live my Animal Crossing (the first, thatÂ is) days, whenÂ everyoneÂ in my family loved videoÂ games, aside from my uncle who still does, and everyone at school loved Nintendo with a passion... :'(
Edit: Hey, at least I have a few friends in school that like Nintendo like me!
And one's a girl! :D
Plus, there's the internet! (and my cousin HAS sorta tried to bond with me, so no harm I guess)
